Model Building
We fitted a Bayesian Generalised Additive Model (GAM) with a Gamma response in brms (Bürkner 2017, 2018, 2021) to explain the geometric-mean chlorophyll-a concentration (GeoMean_Chla) in for each of the 10 sites.
We modeled chlorophyll-a concentration (Chla) as a strictly positive, right-skewed response using a Gamma distribution with a log link. Three key environmental drivers—sea-surface temperature (SST), ice cover (IceCover) and wind speed (WindSpeed)—were each entered as thin-plate regression splines whose shape was allowed to vary by Region, thus capturing potentially different non‐linear responses across regions. Weakly regularizing priors were placed on the intercept (Student-t(3, 0, 2.5)), on each spline’s smoothing standard deviation (half-Student-t(3, 0, 2.5)), and on the Gamma shape parameter φ (Gamma(0.01, 0.01)).
Posterior inference was carried out via the NUTS Hamiltonian Monte Carlo sampler in brms (Bürkner 2017, 2018, 2021) with 4 chains, each run for 5 000 iterations (500 warm-up, 4500 post-warm-up). Convergence and sampling quality were assessed by inspecting the Gelman–Rubin statistic (all R̂ ≤ 1.01) and bulk and tail effective sample sizes (all > 1 000), confirming thorough exploration of the joint posterior.
\[\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{Chla}_i \;\bigl|\;\mu_i,\phi\bigr.
&\sim \operatorname{Gamma}\bigl(\,\mathrm{shape} = \phi,\;\mathrm{rate} = \tfrac{\phi}{\mu_i}\bigr), \\[4pt]

E[\mathrm{Chla}_i] = \mu_i, \\[6pt]

\log(\mu_i) &= \eta_i, \\[4pt]

\eta_i
&= \alpha
   + f_1\bigl(\mathrm{SST}_i \mid \mathrm{Region}_i\bigr)
   + f_2\bigl(\mathrm{IceCover}_i \mid \mathrm{Region}_i\bigr)
   + f_3\bigl(\mathrm{WindSpeed}_i \mid \mathrm{Region}_i\bigr),
   \\[8pt]

f_j(x \mid r)
&= \sum_{k=1}^{K_j} \beta_{jkr}\,B_{jk}(x),
\quad j = 1,2,3,\; r = 1,\dots,R, \\[10pt]

\alpha &\sim t_{3}(0,\,2.5), \\[2pt]
\beta_{jkr} &\sim \mathcal{N}\bigl(0,\sigma_j^{2}\bigr), \\[2pt]
\sigma_j &\sim t^{+}_{3}(0,\,2.5),
\quad j = 1,2,3, \\[2pt]
\phi    &\sim \mathrm{Gamma}(0.01,\,0.01).
\end{aligned}\]
